subject: Add full russian translation
commitMessage:
Add full russian translation

This localisation was performed by a native speaker well familiar with
server administration and passed internal reviews by other GAGAR>IN
administrators.

Signed-off-by: Pavel Zhukov <p.zhukov@gagar-in.com>
Signed-off-by: Andrei Tutolmin <a.tutolmin@gagar-in.com>
Signed-off-by: Paul Fertser <fercerpav@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Iea6a22351dcd999bd094e530229c7aee7e8e9629

comments.message:

Build Successful 

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-repository/16379/ : SUCCESS

Patch Set 1:

Добрый день!

Случайно наткнулся на коммит с добавлением поддержки русского языка в webui-vue.
Сам постарался вычитать, что мог, но мне кажется подобное изменение нуждается в помощи всего русcкоязычного комьюнити OpenBMC.

Оригинал JSON: https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/src/locales/en-US.json

Patch Set 1:

BTW, thank you everybody for the feedback, I know GAGAR>IN team is working on digesting and incorporating it as time permits.

Patch Set 1:

For the future reference, this command in the root of webui-vue sources helps to see all missing translations (those that are missing in both en-US and ru-RU are false positives):
```
node node_modules/vue-i18n-extract/bin/vue-i18n-extract.js -v 'src/**/*.?(js|vue)' -l 'src/locales/?(en-US|ru-RU).json'
```

Patch Set 5:

Hello Derick. Can you please tell if anything's still missing wrt this change?

Patch Set 5:

> Patch Set 5:
> 
> Hello Derick. Can you please tell if anything's still missing wrt this change?

I will set aside time to review if you have updated every property. I do have a question. Are you planning to own this as property names and content changes. We haven't done full translation as we are still in the process of developing the application and there are many changes coming that may require changes.

Patch Set 5:

Hi Derick,

> > Patch Set 5:
> > 
> > Hello Derick. Can you please tell if anything's still missing wrt this change?
> 
> I will set aside time to review if you have updated every property. 

This discussion thread mentions the procedure I used to verify that. If it is sound, then it should mean this patch does add translation for every translatable property.

> I do have a question. Are you planning to own this as property names and content changes. We haven't done full translation as we are still in the process of developing the application and there are many changes coming that may require changes.

I can't say GAGAR>IN company is going to promise to keep this translation up-to-date (it needs additional discussions with the management). Please also see earlier comments here where I proved with detailed examples that people are used to seeing incomplete translations in Free Software projects and that a mostly-complete translation is considered to be better than an absent one. Please also see the Reviewers list which I assume means there's a sizable Russian-speaking OpenBMC community so I'd expect any missing translation to be crowd-sourced in reasonable time.

Patch Set 5:

I'll merge, but would like to state that I have concerns about not having a plan to update the translations as content changes. I don't just mean when new things are added. It is possible that copy will change and that will leave the translation out of sync. We will be making many changes downstream and will only be translating our downstream content and we are only doing so after a freeze for a planned release.
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 678390cd88d939ac0af3841074d1588f0666bea6 by Paul Fertser

Patch Set 6:

Hello,
Any russian-speaking volunteers willing to contribute? Recent commits added and changed some items so following https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/45149 I see 54 untranslated keys at the moment (plus country names which should probably be simply copied from en-US).

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> Hello,
> Any russian-speaking volunteers willing to contribute? Recent commits added and changed some items so following https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/45149 I see 54 untranslated keys at the moment (plus country names which should probably be simply copied from en-US).

If keys are not going to be translated, is there value in copying them over to Russian? Any missing keys will fallback to en-US. Sorry if I am not understanding.

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > Patch Set 6:
> > 
> > Hello,
> > Any russian-speaking volunteers willing to contribute? Recent commits added and changed some items so following https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/45149 I see 54 untranslated keys at the moment (plus country names which should probably be simply copied from en-US).
> 
> If keys are not going to be translated, is there value in copying them over to Russian? Any missing keys will fallback to en-US. Sorry if I am not understanding.

My only rationale for suggesting that was to avoid needless visual clutter in the vue-i18n-extract.js output plus it would be adding all of the missing keys with empty values every time when run with -a.
Thinking a bit more about this, the right way would be to either decide that the language names shouldn't be translated ever at all (if they're used in the language selection drop-down menu they should probably always be either in English or each language name should be written in the language itself, again, not requiring any translation, in other words, not calling $t) or if there's a reason for translation then a proper one must be added. Thanks for spotting the weak point in my logic here :)

Patch Set 6:

So now with the easy tooling instructions merged, countries list merged is there anything else needed for you Russian-speaking folks to start contributing the missing translations?

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> So now with the easy tooling instructions merged, countries list merged is there anything else needed for you Russian-speaking folks to start contributing the missing translations?

Is there a way to place the missing keys in the same position they are exist in the `en-US.json` file?
Because right now it looks like every new key is placed at the end of its dictionary.


I've executed:
```
node node_modules/vue-i18n-extract/bin/vue-i18n-extract.js -v 'src/**/*.?(js|vue)' -l 'src/locales/ru-RU.json' -a
```

And then have compared the JSON files with vimdiff:
```
vimdiff src/locales/ru-RU.json src/locales/en-US.json
```

Patch Set 6:

> > So now with the easy tooling instructions merged, countries list merged is there anything else needed for you Russian-speaking folks to start contributing the missing translations?
> 
> Is there a way to place the missing keys in the same position they are exist in the `en-US.json` file?
> Because right now it looks like every new key is placed at the end of its dictionary.

I'm afraid there's no way to do that automatically, might worth filing a feature request for vue-i18n-extract.js. I can see how it can be useful for easier cross-referencing with the en-US but alas.

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > > So now with the easy tooling instructions merged, countries list merged is there anything else needed for you Russian-speaking folks to start contributing the missing translations?
> > 
> > Is there a way to place the missing keys in the same position they are exist in the `en-US.json` file?
> > Because right now it looks like every new key is placed at the end of its dictionary.
> 
> I'm afraid there's no way to do that automatically, might worth filing a feature request for vue-i18n-extract.js. I can see how it can be useful for easier cross-referencing with the en-US but alas.

FYI -> There will be changes needed after the IA stories are complete and merged. It will break navigation translation in Russian. Since none of our team speak or read Russian, we are not going to update the properties that are changed in the en-US file so that it's clear what needs to be resolved.

Regarding this conversation, this is one of the reasons we are not translating anything until our release and we will send the en-US file to be translated in several different languages based on the content that is frozen for the release.

Patch Set 6:

(18 comments)

> Any missing keys will fallback to en-US

That's good to know. What happens if the key exists, but the value is an empty string? Will it fall back to en-US too or will it use that empty string?

Patch Set 6:

Damn it! Didn't notice the outdated drafts. Please disregard them.

Patch Set 6:

> > Any missing keys will fallback to en-US
> 
> That's good to know. What happens if the key exists, but the value is an empty string? Will it fall back to en-US too or will it use that empty string?

Just tried it on login page. One label is empty, another not generated at all. The button is empty. So yes, it's using the empty string.

Patch Set 6:

> Regarding this conversation, this is one of the reasons we are not translating anything until our release and we will send the en-US file to be translated in several different languages based on the content that is frozen for the release.

This wording sounds odd. As this change's history shows one can't produce a decent translation without actually using it, and without the feedback from people having experience using similar products. For that webui-vue needs to be built from the sources, and the sources include en-US file already. So why and where to would you be sending that file? And how is the OpenBMC community going to be involved in the process?

Patch Set 6:

> Patch Set 6:
> 
> > Regarding this conversation, this is one of the reasons we are not translating anything until our release and we will send the en-US file to be translated in several different languages based on the content that is frozen for the release.
> 
> This wording sounds odd. As this change's history shows one can't produce a decent translation without actually using it, and without the feedback from people having experience using similar products. For that webui-vue needs to be built from the sources, and the sources include en-US file already. So why and where to would you be sending that file? And how is the OpenBMC community going to be involved in the process?

We freeze for translation prior to a release for many products. Our plan is to do this downstream as there will be changes we need to make to meet our customer needs and some of the changes will not meet community needs. I don't believe the plan is to push the translations upstream. We discussed this in a previous design work group meeting.

A drive by comment.

How is maintenance of this going to work?  I don't see any additional maintainers being added in the patchset, and I wouldn't expect that the current maintainers speak or write Russian, so that seems like we're leaving some scenarios unaddressed.

When new features are added that would require a Russian (or any other language for that matter) translation, does the patch get held up until the new fields are added?

Who will verify those translations for correctness?

Is there some fallback behavior we need to define such that the code falls back to SOMETHING if the translations aren't available?

For what it's worth, I suspect we'll also need a very similar set up for when we have multi-language redfish message registries, so if we can solve it here, when we get to the message registry issue, we can just do the same thing.



As a strawman, I would propose that each new language being added also adds a maintainer of said language, and said person is willing to support keeping the translation table up to date within 4 weeks of any patchset adding a new feature being added to the English side.  Developers writing new features or updating existing features with fields that require translation will not be required to check in the russian translation itself, but will be responsible for adding the new IDs and "NULL" to the json table, so that the maintainers can track where the appropriate translations need to be added.

Hello Ed,
You can try Spanish translation now (and it's quite minimal) to see that webui is just showing English where it lacks translated string. So I think there's no need for those who add new features to bother with anything, just use proper terminology in English, and then whoever would want to have it in another language would send an update to the translation eventually.
Finding untranslated strings is easy without doing anything extra too, as the vue i18n library employed ships with a tool to do just that. (offtopic: please check my documentation amendments for phosphor-pid-control or tell me what I am doing wrong regarding it)

> Hello Ed,
> You can try Spanish translation now (and it's quite minimal) to see that webui is just showing English where it lacks translated string.

I wasn't on the review for the spanish translation, but in terms of an upstream feature, it seems quite broken, and unless i'm mistaken, it's not optional.  I'm a little surprised it got merged without this problem being solved, and without at least a complete translation table.  That seems like it would lead to the upstream code always being broken.

> So I think there's no need for those who add new features to bother with anything, just use proper terminology in English, and then whoever would want to have it in another language would send an update to the translation eventually.

This seems reasonable, but somewhat misses the point.  Now that the author has effectively broken a language for a given feature, who is going to be responsible for fixing it?  "Wait until someone pushes a patch to fix it" doesn't seem maintainable, and would lead to at least one language being broken somewhere at any given point in time, which doesn't seem stable to me.

> Finding untranslated strings is easy without doing anything extra too, as the vue i18n library employed ships with a tool to do just that.

Good to know that it's easy to find the breakages, although I would really like something in code so a maintainer can easily scan the translation file and find all the places it's needed.  For those that know the language, I don't see the translation as that onerous, but requiring that everyone learn a new tool to do it seems like it's a barrier to getting stuff done, and makes it harder to code review "did you handle all the cases".


> (offtopic: please check my documentation amendments for phosphor-pid-control or tell me what I am doing wrong regarding it)

Josh is mostly dealing with phosphor pid control at the moment, you might try pinging him.

> > So I think there's no need for those who add new features to bother with anything, just use proper terminology in English, and then whoever would want to have it in another language would send an update to the translation eventually.
> 
> This seems reasonable, but somewhat misses the point.  Now that the author has effectively broken a language for a given feature, who is going to be responsible for fixing it?  "Wait until someone pushes a patch to fix it" doesn't seem maintainable, and would lead to at least one language being broken somewhere at any given point in time, which doesn't seem stable to me.

My personal impression is that if the software falls back to English for untranslated strings it's not really breaking anything, just new features are untranslated for a while until someone cares. Is this really a big deal? I thought it's the norm for the free software projects.

> > Finding untranslated strings is easy without doing anything extra too, as the vue i18n library employed ships with a tool to do just that.
> 
> Good to know that it's easy to find the breakages, although I would really like something in code so a maintainer can easily scan the translation file and find all the places it's needed.

Yes, the tool is already included in webui-vue (see my last comment with an example of how it can be run), and its output is straightforward to follow, nothing to learn really (assuming webvui-ui contributors know JSON syntax).

It might make sense to keep a list of people interested in keeping localisations up-to-date, and for the current "update" hook to print it whenever a new item requiring translation is added so that when the change is submitted to Gerrit the author had an effortless way to notify potential translators.

But requiring some strict maintainership in this area feels unrealistic and counter-productive to me. And AFAICT it's not how it's usually done in the free software world.

I guess here you might want to hear the opinions of people who actually use (and enjoy?) localised software, I'm not the one to judge.

> > > So I think there's no need for those who add new features to bother with anything, just use proper terminology in English, and then whoever would want to have it in another language would send an update to the translation eventually.
> > 
> > This seems reasonable, but somewhat misses the point.  Now that the author has effectively broken a language for a given feature, who is going to be responsible for fixing it?  "Wait until someone pushes a patch to fix it" doesn't seem maintainable, and would lead to at least one language being broken somewhere at any given point in time, which doesn't seem stable to me.
> 
> My personal impression is that if the software falls back to English for untranslated strings it's not really breaking anything, just new features are untranslated for a while until someone cares. Is this really a big deal? I thought it's the norm for the free software projects.

That seems pretty broken to me.  Can you point at any other open source projects that have this translation policy?  I'd be interested to see how it works.

From my perspective, this model seems like an issue, as language support isn't optional, so anyone that wants a working system has no path to say "I don't care about languages other than english because it's broken"  If there was that option, I think "break things until someone cares to fix it" might be better, but I'd still think we need maintainers for each language, even if they aren't held to providing translations in a relatively short amount of time.

> 
> > > Finding untranslated strings is easy without doing anything extra too, as the vue i18n library employed ships with a tool to do just that.
> > 
> > Good to know that it's easy to find the breakages, although I would really like something in code so a maintainer can easily scan the translation file and find all the places it's needed.
> 
> Yes, the tool is already included in webui-vue (see my last comment with an example of how it can be run), and its output is straightforward to follow, nothing to learn really (assuming webvui-ui contributors know JSON syntax).

The fact that you had to write instructions means it requires some learning.  Gerrit definitely doesn't know how to run the tool.

> 
> It might make sense to keep a list of people interested in keeping localisations up-to-date, and for the current "update" hook to print it whenever a new item requiring translation is added so that when the change is submitted to Gerrit the author had an effortless way to notify potential translators.

This is where I kind of like the "new keys need to be added as null" approach.  We would just write owners files for each translation file, and the relevant owners would be added to the review any time that file is changed.

> 
> But requiring some strict maintainership in this area feels unrealistic and counter-productive to me. And AFAICT it's not how it's usually done in the free software world.

I'm not following this.  maintainership is definitely a thing in open source, and is used a lot in OpenBMC.  We've rejected many things because there was no one willing to maintain it as has many other projects.  Allowing new patchsets to break things (by adding new features that require translations) that are currently working, without having a plan to fix it seems like an issue to me and would just lead to translations being totally broken (like the spanish translation is today), which is especially a problem if they're required in the build, as I now have no way to build a non-broken version of software.  For what it's worth, the fact that nobody wanted to write a translation file is what largely stopped the translation feature from phsophor-webui when I maintained it in the past.


With that said, i'm not the maintainer here, so I'd be interested to see what they have to say.

> 
> I guess here you might want to hear the opinions of people who actually use (and enjoy?) localised software, I'm not the one to judge.

For sure I can imagine the appeal, and I have no problem with localized software in general or in open source.  I have a problem with the plan being that we'll just break the localization feature every week, and won't have anyone capable and responsible for cleaning it up.  If we can solve that, I think it would be a great addition to webui-vue, and very useful to users.

> > My personal impression is that if the software falls back to English for untranslated strings it's not really breaking anything, just new features are untranslated for a while until someone cares. Is this really a big deal? I thought it's the norm for the free software projects.
> 
> That seems pretty broken to me.  Can you point at any other open source projects that have this translation policy?  I'd be interested to see how it works.

Since I read your message in mutt (I have an impression it's likely the most popular console MUA atm) I just did "git clone https://gitlab.com/muttmua/mutt" and checked "git log po/" in there. Since this discussion is directly related to Russian I took a look at the last commits affecting po/ru.po . Change 3e9c605db7dd6e7d07f427609518df87cd99efd6 shows that before 2020-05-02 and 2020-11-06 nobody was updating the translation. And that commit added 91 new strings! Now about half a year later I did "autoreconf -i; ./configure; cd po; make mutt.pot; msgmerge -o ru.po ru.po mutt.pot; git diff | grep '\+msgstr' | wc -l" and that says 57 new untranslated strings were added since then. So apparently that's just the way it is, it's OK to have plenty of untranslated items at just about any moment?
 
> From my perspective, this model seems like an issue, as language support isn't optional, so anyone that wants a working system has no path to say "I don't care about languages other than english because it's broken" 

This is probably a terminology argument now because I wouldn't call it "broken" if most of the strings are translated and some few new features are shown in English. Not sure what those who actually use localised software are thinking though.

> > Yes, the tool is already included in webui-vue (see my last comment with an example of how it can be run), and its output is straightforward to follow, nothing to learn really (assuming webvui-ui contributors know JSON syntax).
> 
> The fact that you had to write instructions means it requires some learning.  Gerrit definitely doesn't know how to run the tool.

I do not see a reason to run the tool unless one is going to add missing translations, so I do not see why it might need to be part of a CI process, sorry.

> > It might make sense to keep a list of people interested in keeping localisations up-to-date, and for the current "update" hook to print it whenever a new item requiring translation is added so that when the change is submitted to Gerrit the author had an effortless way to notify potential translators.
> 
> This is where I kind of like the "new keys need to be added as null" approach.  We would just write owners files for each translation file, and the relevant owners would be added to the review any time that file is changed.

That might work but it seems like that's not the workflow vue-i18n authors had in mind.

> > But requiring some strict maintainership in this area feels unrealistic and counter-productive to me. And AFAICT it's not how it's usually done in the free software world.
> 
> I'm not following this.  maintainership is definitely a thing in open source, and is used a lot in OpenBMC.  We've rejected many things because there was no one willing to maintain it as has many other projects.  Allowing new patchsets to break things (by adding new features that require translations) that are currently working, without having a plan to fix it seems like an issue to me and would just lead to translations being totally broken (like the spanish translation is today), which is especially a problem if they're required in the build, as I now have no way to build a non-broken version of software.  

Well, if you insist on calling partial translation "broken", I have to agree. However that goes contrary to what I saw previously; I have drive-by contributions to many different projects, and I do not remember anyone ever caring when new strings potentially requiring translations were added.

> For what it's worth, the fact that nobody wanted to write a translation file is what largely stopped the translation feature from phsophor-webui when I maintained it in the past.

Here with vue-i18n it's supposed to be automatic AFAICT.

> > > My personal impression is that if the software falls back to English for untranslated strings it's not really breaking anything, just new features are untranslated for a while until someone cares. Is this really a big deal? I thought it's the norm for the free software projects.
> > 
> > That seems pretty broken to me.  Can you point at any other open source projects that have this translation policy?  I'd be interested to see how it works.
> 
> Since I read your message in mutt (I have an impression it's likely the most popular console MUA atm) I just did "git clone https://gitlab.com/muttmua/mutt" and checked "git log po/" in there. Since this discussion is directly related to Russian I took a look at the last commits affecting po/ru.po . Change 3e9c605db7dd6e7d07f427609518df87cd99efd6 shows that before 2020-05-02 and 2020-11-06 nobody was updating the translation. And that commit added 91 new strings! Now about half a year later I did "autoreconf -i; ./configure; cd po; make mutt.pot; msgmerge -o ru.po ru.po mutt.pot; git diff | grep '\+msgstr' | wc -l" and that says 57 new untranslated strings were added since then. So apparently that's just the way it is, it's OK to have plenty of untranslated items at just about any moment?

It's ok for mutt.  Considering a number of openbmc systems are sold and have support contracts, I suspect it's a slightly different model, but your point is well taken, there are projects whre it's a "best effort" type activity.  Do you know how mutt fails over when translations aren't available?

>  
> > From my perspective, this model seems like an issue, as language support isn't optional, so anyone that wants a working system has no path to say "I don't care about languages other than english because it's broken" 
> 
> This is probably a terminology argument now because I wouldn't call it "broken" if most of the strings are translated and some few new features are shown in English. Not sure what those who actually use localised software are thinking though.


As someone who has developed a BMC that supported multiple languages (not openbmc) there were definitely bugs filed for both inability to remove a language support entirely, as well as individual strings that were missing.  OpenBMC is a slightly different animal in that it's open source, but I suspect will suffer from the same issue.  I know if I saw a translation option that didn't translate certain things, I would probably call that a bug, but maybe we differ in our thoughts there.

With that said, if we have a method for a developer to opt into the languages they want, I think this problem goes away entirely for the webui, as developers that care will keep the translations up to date, and those that don't can just disable the languages so they don't show up.  That won't work for redfish message registries like I was hoping it would (because there's no fallback defined) but we can solve that problem later.

> 
> > > Yes, the tool is already included in webui-vue (see my last comment with an example of how it can be run), and its output is straightforward to follow, nothing to learn really (assuming webvui-ui contributors know JSON syntax).
> > 
> > The fact that you had to write instructions means it requires some learning.  Gerrit definitely doesn't know how to run the tool.
> 
> I do not see a reason to run the tool unless one is going to add missing translations, so I do not see why it might need to be part of a CI process, sorry.

Fair point.

> 
> > > It might make sense to keep a list of people interested in keeping localisations up-to-date, and for the current "update" hook to print it whenever a new item requiring translation is added so that when the change is submitted to Gerrit the author had an effortless way to notify potential translators.
> > 
> > This is where I kind of like the "new keys need to be added as null" approach.  We would just write owners files for each translation file, and the relevant owners would be added to the review any time that file is changed.
> 
> That might work but it seems like that's not the workflow vue-i18n authors had in mind.

fair, doing more "standard" things probably helps us in this regard.

> 
> > > But requiring some strict maintainership in this area feels unrealistic and counter-productive to me. And AFAICT it's not how it's usually done in the free software world.
> > 
> > I'm not following this.  maintainership is definitely a thing in open source, and is used a lot in OpenBMC.  We've rejected many things because there was no one willing to maintain it as has many other projects.  Allowing new patchsets to break things (by adding new features that require translations) that are currently working, without having a plan to fix it seems like an issue to me and would just lead to translations being totally broken (like the spanish translation is today), which is especially a problem if they're required in the build, as I now have no way to build a non-broken version of software.  
> 
> Well, if you insist on calling partial translation "broken", I have to agree. However that goes contrary to what I saw previously; I have drive-by contributions to many different projects, and I do not remember anyone ever caring when new strings potentially requiring translations were added.

Ok, that's a good data point to have.

> 
> > For what it's worth, the fact that nobody wanted to write a translation file is what largely stopped the translation feature from phsophor-webui when I maintained it in the past.
> 
> Here with vue-i18n it's supposed to be automatic AFAICT.

> Do you know how mutt fails over when translations aren't available?

Yes, mutt is using GNU Gettext library (as many other projects do), and official documentation https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/manual/html_node/Interface-to-gettext.html says "The translation of the string msgid is returned if it is available in the current domain. If it is not available, the argument itself is returned." And it's customary to use plain English messages for msgid.

I'm told that the same happens with other popular software, e.g. LibreOffice, where one can usually see plenty of untranslated items with each new release.

On the server boards we're dealing with a UEFI implementation from Phoenix (with some UI parts coming directly from Intel) and it's another example of having partial translations (not a single additional language has all the strings afaict), it just shows English wherever a translation is missing and apparently everybody's ok with that. 
 
> ... if we have a method for a developer to opt into the languages they want, I think this problem goes away entirely for the webui

I fully agree here; unfortunately, I'm not the one who can offer a patch to add a suitable method as I do not have any clue about JS and Vue.

> > Do you know how mutt fails over when translations aren't available?
> 
> Yes, mutt is using GNU Gettext library (as many other projects do), and official documentation https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/manual/html_node/Interface-to-gettext.html says "The translation of the string msgid is returned if it is available in the current domain. If it is not available, the argument itself is returned." And it's customary to use plain English messages for msgid.
> 
> I'm told that the same happens with other popular software, e.g. LibreOffice, where one can usually see plenty of untranslated items with each new release.
> 
> On the server boards we're dealing with a UEFI implementation from Phoenix (with some UI parts coming directly from Intel) and it's another example of having partial translations (not a single additional language has all the strings afaict), it just shows English wherever a translation is missing and apparently everybody's ok with that. 
>  
> > ... if we have a method for a developer to opt into the languages they want, I think this problem goes away entirely for the webui
> 
> I fully agree here; unfortunately, I'm not the one who can offer a patch to add a suitable method as I do not have any clue about JS and Vue.

Cool, sounds like we agree.  Now it's probably up to the maintainers to see what they want to do.  I still wish I could've used this as a model for message registry, which requires translations to exist for all elements, but oh well, we'll cross that bridge when we get there.

Hm, I thought to use "Вкл"/"Выкл" for "on"/"off". The reasons: 
1) they are same short
2) "enabled"/"disabled" and "Включено"/"Выключено" are state, while "on"/"off" and "Вкл"/"Выкл" could be both state and action.

Why did you decide too use "Вкл"/"Выкл" for "enabled"/"disabled"? Is there any objections based on real usage in the code?
Where does "UEFI" comes from? Not all systems which OpenBMC runs on have UEFI as host firmware, so I don't think it is good idea to mention it here.

Although I'm usually for 'ё', I would keep 'е' here as I figure this is like "Очистить все записи", not like "Уничтожить всё, что есть".
This is a very controversial term in Russian. "Загрузить" may mean both "download" and "upload". I would change to "Скачать", which despite being more colloquial is much less ambiguous.
This may have problems fitting into the UI. May be change it to "Изменить" ?

If you use 'между', then an 'и' is expected, not an m-dash.
That is, "между %{min} и %{max}".

I feel this may result in some weird looking strings like "Индикатор сервера: Включено" and "Статус учётной записи: Выключено".

When the original language doesn't have a concept of inclinations and gender for nouns and verbs, it is very hard to translate such things properly. Unfortunately, people who initially did i18n in VUE were speaking one of those languages and so didn't think about that. Thus we now have to invent various kludges to work around that.

To avoid the gender-specific endings I would use just the traditional 'Вкл' and 'Выкл' here, just like you do for 'on' and 'off'.
Maybe make this 'Н/Д' to avoid wrong gender endings?
This is only used as a toast header. I suggest "Успех". A noun looks better as a heading than an adjective.

Luckily it is only used in context of numbers like 10, 20, 30, and 40. If it was used also for numbers < 5, or (20+n*10+(1..4)), we would be in big trouble. 😊

Anyway, since this is for tables only and so refers to table rows, I would say
'Записей на страницу'.
Again, this is about table rows. I suggest 'Выбрать запись' here.
